title: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group, Phase 2 Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of CT1812 in Subjects With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease.
description_brief: This is a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel group 36 week multicenter Phase 2 study of two doses of CT1812 in adults with mild to moderate Alzheimer's Disease (AD).
description_detailed:
This is a multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel group 36 week multicenter Phase 2 study of two doses of CT1812 in adults with mild to moderate Alzheimer's Disease (AD).

This Phase 2 study is designed to evaluate the safety of two doses of CT1812 administered once daily for 6 months in adults aged 50 to 85 who have been diagnosed with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. Randomized participants will receive 100 mg of CT1812, 300 mg of CT1812, or placebo once daily for 182 days. Exploratory endpoints that evaluate the effect of CT1812 on biomarkers are also included.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: A total of 372 participants were screened, and 153 were randomized: 51 to CT1812 100 mg, 51 to CT1812 300 mg, and 51 to placebo. Study drug was administered to all participants in the CT1812 groups (100%) and to 50 participants (98.0%) in the placebo group. One participant in the placebo arm was randomized in error and did not receive study drug after informing the site post-randomization and prior to dosing of a prohibited concomitant medication.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: The study was conducted in 12 centers in the United States, 3 centers in Australia, 3 centers in the Netherlands, 8 centers in Czech Republic, and 4 centers in Spain.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: One participant in the placebo arm was randomized in error and did not receive the study drug after informing the site, post-randomization and prior to dosing, about a prohibited concomitant medication. Therefore, the number of participants in the placebo arm is 50, not 51.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Study Participants With at Least One Mild, Moderate, or Severe Treatment Emergent Adverse Events (TEAEs)
outcomeMeasures.description: Adverse events were captured from the start of study-related procedures at Visit 1 (including diagnostic assessments or signing of ICF) onward during the course of this study. Adverse events were coded using MedDRA Version 27.0.TEAEs are events that occurred or worsened on or after the first application of study drug. Participants are counted once for each system organ class (SOC) and once for each preferred term (PT).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Data are based on the safety population, which is defined as all participants who received one or more doses of the study drug.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in the Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Biomarkers
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in CSF-Aβ, Tau, phospho-Tau, neurogranin, synaptotagmin, synaptosomal-associated protein-25 (SNAP25), neurofilament light chain (NfL), and Aβ-oligomers.Change from baseline is calculated as the observed value minus the baseline value.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The analyzed population represents the number of subjects in the Efficacy modified intent-to-treat (mITT) population and participants who had both baseline and Day 182 CSF samples collected.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse events were captured from the start of study-related procedures at Visit 1 (- 60 to -1 days) until the safety follow up visit V15 (study day 210 (±2) days). Important medical events and conditions occurring prior to this period were not recorded as AEs; they were captured within the medical chart and in the medical history section of the CRF.
adverseEventsModule.description: The safety of CT1812 was evaluated by the incidence and severity of adverse events (AEs) and changes in the usage of concomitant medications, vital signs, physical examination findings, electrocardiogram (ECG) findings, clinical laboratory testing (serum chemistry, hematology, and urinalysis), and Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS).

drug: CT1812 (Elayta) — oral small-molecule allosteric antagonist of the sigma‑2 receptor complex (TMEM97) that displaces amyloid‑β (Aβ) oligomers from neurons
explanation_target: Reason: CT1812 is described in the literature as an oral small‑molecule, allosteric antagonist of the sigma‑2 receptor complex (TMEM97) that prevents and displaces Aβ oligomer binding to neurons, aiming to reduce downstream synaptotoxicity — i.e., it targets Alzheimer's pathology rather than being a biologic or purely symptomatic cognitive enhancer. citeturn0search2turn0search4

Act: From the trial description you gave (Phase 2 randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study of CT1812 in mild–moderate AD) and the drug profile above, the appropriate category is 'disease‑targeted small molecule' because CT1812 is a small‑molecule therapeutic directed at an AD pathogenic mechanism (Aβ oligomer–sigma‑2/TMEM97 interaction). (CT1812 is also referred to as Elayta in some publications.) citeturn0search3turn0search1

Reflect: This classification is consistent across clinical reports and reviews: CT1812 is not a biologic (no monoclonal antibody or vaccine), it is a small molecule with a disease‑modifying rationale (displacing amyloid oligomers), and its clinical studies have been in Phase 1/2 and early Phase 2 AD trials — therefore 'disease‑targeted small molecule' is the best fit. Note: clinical efficacy on cognition remains to be demonstrated in larger/longer trials. citeturn0search4turn0search6

Web search results (key sources consulted): 1) Phase 1 description and mechanism summary (PubMed): CT1812 (Elayta) is an allosteric sigma‑2 receptor antagonist that displaces Aβ oligomers. citeturn0search2. 2) Pilot/Phase 1‑2 and SPARC study reports showing safety/tolerability and biomarker endpoints in mild–moderate AD. citeturn0search3. 3) Systematic reviews and reviews summarizing clinical data and mechanism (CT1812 as σ‑2/TMEM97 antagonist; small‑molecule approach). citeturn0search4turn0search5.
explanation_agent: Reason: CT1812 (Elayta) is an oral small‑molecule allosteric antagonist of the sigma‑2 receptor complex (TMEM97) that displaces amyloid‑β (Aβ) oligomers from neuronal receptors and aims to reduce downstream synaptotoxicity — the drug’s described mechanism is removal/prevention of Aβ oligomer binding, i.e., it targets amyloid pathology. citeturn0search2turn0search7

Act: The trial tests CT1812 as a disease‑targeted small molecule whose primary therapeutic rationale is displacement of Aβ oligomers; under CADRO this maps to A) Amyloid beta (the intervention is directed at amyloid‑β oligomer pathology rather than purely symptomatic neurotransmitter effects). citeturn0search0turn0search4

Reflect: Alternate reading: the molecular binding site is the sigma‑2/TMEM97 receptor (a non‑amyloid protein). However, CADRO classes are organized by the Alzheimer’s pathology/pathway targeted — because CT1812’s intended disease effect is to displace Aβ oligomers and mitigate amyloid‑mediated synaptotoxicity, A) Amyloid beta is the most specific and appropriate CADRO category. I confirm this assignment while noting CT1812 is a sigma‑2/TMEM97 antagonist by mechanism. citeturn0search7turn0search2

Web search results (key sources consulted): 1) Systematic review summarizing CT1812 mechanism and clinical data (Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease, 2024). citeturn0search0 2) Phase 1 clinical trial paper describing CT1812 as a σ‑2/TMEM97 allosteric antagonist that displaces Aβ oligomers and reporting early safety/tolerability. citeturn0search2turn0search6 3) Pilot Phase 1/2 biomarker study in mild–moderate AD (safety, biomarker endpoints; displacement signal reported). citeturn0search4 4) Alzforum summary and trial updates (development status, additional studies). citeturn0search3 5) Trial registry / Phase 2 (START/other) listings (study design, populations). citeturn0search1turn0search5 6) Reviews explaining σ‑2 receptor = TMEM97 and link to Aβ oligomer binding. citeturn0search7 7) News coverage of recent phase‑2 efficacy reporting (context on outcomes). citeturn0news12
